<div style="color:green; font-weight:bold; font-size:22px;">Workshop Title:</div>

<div style="font-size:20px;"><strong>Modeling Longitudinal Data with Time-Dependent Covariates</strong></div>

<hr>

<div style="color:green; font-weight:bold; font-size:22px;">Course Description:</div>

<p>This applied workshop introduces practical strategies for modeling longitudinal data with time-dependent covariates, using real-world examples from health, behavioral, and policy research.</p>

<p>Time-dependent covariates—such as changing medication use, behavioral exposures, or symptom scores—pose unique challenges in longitudinal studies.</p>

<p>Participants will learn how to recognize and model these variables using:</p>

<ul>
  <li>Marginal models (e.g., GEE)</li>
  <li>Mixed-effects models</li>
  <li>Joint modeling frameworks</li>
</ul>

<p>Through a combination of lecture and live coding demonstrations, the workshop will emphasize:</p>

<ul>
  <li>Modeling feedback</li>
  <li>Covariate timing</li>
  <li>Dynamic exposure-outcome relationships</li>
</ul>

<p>Hands-on examples will be provided in both <strong>SAS</strong> and <strong>R</strong>, with optional demonstrations in <strong>Stan</strong> for Bayesian extensions.</p>

<p>By the end of the workshop, participants will be equipped to build, estimate, and interpret longitudinal models that incorporate time-dependent covariates for both <strong>continuous</strong> and <strong>binary</strong> outcomes.</p>

<hr>

<div style="color:green; font-weight:bold; font-size:22px;">Prerequisites:</div>

<ul>
  <li>A course in regression</li>
  <li>Familiarity with longitudinal data structure and basic statistical inference</li>
  <li>Prior experience using <strong>R</strong> or <strong>SAS</strong> is helpful but not required</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<div style="color:green; font-weight:bold; font-size:22px;">Learning Objectives:</div>

<p>By the end of the workshop, participants will be able to:</p>

<ol>
  <li>Differentiate between time-independent and time-dependent covariates in longitudinal data</li>
  <li>Understand the implications of using time-dependent covariates in marginal, conditional, and joint models</li>
  <li>Identify situations involving feedback, endogeneity, and measurement timing</li>
  <li>Implement marginal models using Generalized Estimating Equations (GEE) and linear mixed-effects models</li>
  <li>Fit models with time-dependent covariates using <strong>SAS</strong> and <strong>R</strong></li>
  <li>Interpret model results for time-varying effects and gain insight into dynamic change processes</li>
</ol>

<hr>

<div style="color:green; font-weight:bold; font-size:22px;">Textbook (Recommended):</div>

<p><strong>Wilson, J., Vazquez, E. and Chen, D. G. (2020).</strong><br>
<i>Marginal Models in Analysis of Correlated Binary Data with Time-Dependent Covariates</i>. Springer.<br>
<a href="https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783030489038">Springer Link</a></p>

<hr>

<div style="color:green; font-weight:bold; font-size:22px;">Laptop Requirement:</div>

<p>Yes. Participants should bring a laptop with:</p>

<ul>
  <li><strong>R</strong> and <strong>RStudio</strong> pre-installed</li>
  <li><strong>SAS</strong> (if available)</li>
</ul>

<p>Workshop materials and code examples will be provided in advance.</p>
